[[Fresno State Bulldogs]] }} The San Diego State football team represents the [[San Diego State Aztecs]] in [[college football]]. The Aztecs, a Division I FBS team and a member of the [[Mountain West Conference]], play their home games at [[Qualcomm Stadium]] in [[San Diego, California]]. The field is natural grass and has a maximum capacity of 71,294. The current head coach of the Aztecs is [[Rocky Long]]. Coaching the 2011-12 Aztecs is his first year as the head coach. San Diego State had a 465-359-32 all-time record entering the 2009 football season. They have won thirteen conference championships{{cite web|url=http://www.cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_ia/mountainwest/san_diego_state/conf_champs.php|title=San Diego State Conference Championships}} and three national championships at the small college division. Their rivals are the [[BYU Cougars]], the [[UNLV Rebels]], and the [[Fresno State Bulldogs]].{{cite web|url= http://www.cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_ia/mountainwest/san_diego_state/national_champs.php|title=San Diego State Recognized National Championships}} ==History== San Diego State University was originally two separate schools. San Diego Normal School had school colors of white and gold. San Diego Junior College had school colors of blue and gold. They decided to merge schools in 1921 to form San Diego State College. The first school colors of SDSC were blue, white and gold. During the 1921 school year they had their first football game. The 1943-44 seasons were not played, due to the circumstances involving WWII.{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} Years later the school decided to adopt purple and gold as the new school colors. However, local confusion between the Aztecs and St. Augustine High School forced the school to change their colors yet again. The school voted on new colors and landed on scarlet and black. It is now a very well known tradition that the Aztecs wear all black on home games. ===Night games=== Night games have become a San Diego State University football tradition. The first SDSU night game was played on September 25, 1930 at Lane Field. Over 5,000 fans attended the game to watch the Aztecs beat the San Diego Marines 39-0. Since that day, over 75% of all Aztec games, home and away, have been played at night. ===Bowl appearances=== {| border="1" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" !bgcolor="#e5e5e5"| Year and bowl !! colspan="2" bgcolor="#e5e5e5"| Winning team !! colspan="2" bgcolor="#e5e5e5"| Losing team |- | [[Harbor Bowl|1948 Harbor Bowl]]|| [[Hardin-Simmons University]] || 53 || '''San Diego State''' || '''0''' |- | [Pineapple Bowl|1951 Pineapple Bowl|| '''San Diego State''' || '''34''' || [[Hawaii Warriors football|Hawai{{okina}}i]] || 13 |- | [[Camellia Bowl|1966 Camellia Bowl]]|| '''San Diego State''' || '''28''' || [[Montana State Bobcats football|Montana State]] || 7 |- | [[Camellia Bowl|1967 Camellia Bowl]]|| '''San Diego State''' || '''27''' || [[San Francisco State University|San Francisco State]]|| 6 |- | [[Pasadena Bowl|1969 Pasadena Bowl]]|| '''San Diego State''' || '''28''' || [[Boston University]] || 7 |- | [[1986 Holiday Bowl]]|| [[1986 Iowa Hawkeyes football team|Iowa]] ||39||'''San Diego State''' || '''38''' |- | [[Freedom Bowl|1991 Freedom Bowl]]||[[Tulsa Golden Hurricane football|Tulsa]]|| 28 ||'''San Diego State'''|| '''17''' |- | [[1998 Las Vegas Bowl]] ||[[1998 North Carolina Tar Heels football team|North Carolina]]|| 20 ||'''San Diego State'''|| '''13''' |- | [[2010 Poinsettia Bowl]] ||'''[[2010 San Diego State Aztecs football team|San Diego State]]'''|| '''35''' || [[2010 Navy Midshipmen football team|Navy]]|| 14 |- | [[2011 New Orleans Bowl]] ||[[2011 San Diego State Aztecs football team|San Diego State]]|| || [[2011 LouisianaâLafayette Ragin' Cajuns football team|LouisianaâLafayette]]||played on 12/17/11 |} ===Coaching=== Coach (Alma Mater)/Years/Win Percentage *C.E. Peterson 1921-29, .577 *W.B. Herreid 1930-34, .489 *Leo Calland (Southern Calif. â23) 1935-41, .600 *John Eubank (Washington St. â33) 1942, .071 *Bob Breitbard (San Diego St. â41) 1945, .286 *Bill Terry (Western Kentucky â32) 1946, .600 *Bill Schutte (Idaho â33) 1947-55, .568 *Paul Governali (Columbia â43) 1956-60, .310 *Don Coryell (Washington â50) 1961-72, .840 *Claude Gilbert (San Jose St. â59) 1973-80, .697 *Doug Scovil (Pacific â52) 1981-85, .432 *Denny Stolz (Alma College â55) 1986-88, .457 *Al Luginbill (Cal Poly - Pomona â67) 1989-93, .534 *Ted Tollner (Cal Poly â62) 1994-01, .473 *Tom Craft (San Diego St. â77) 2002-05, .396 *Chuck Long (Iowa â85) 2006-08, .250 *Brady Hoke (Ball State '80) 2009â2011, .520 *Rocky Long (New Mexico '71) 2011-present, .667 In the 2008 season, Brady Hoke was the head coach of the Ball State Cardinals football team. Hoke led the Cardinals to an undefeated regular season and the MAC Championship game. However, after a loss in the championship, Hoke decided to resign. He then signed with the Aztecs in December 2008 to become the new head football coach. After seven games in the 2009 season, Hoke has led the Aztecs to a 3-4 record and a sixth place standing in the Mountain West Conference. In 2010, Hoke led the Aztecs to the school's first nine-win season since 1971 and a victory over Navy in the 2010 Poinsettia Bowl. Hoke left in January 11, 2011 for Michigan. Rocky Long was promoted on January 12, 2011 from defensive coordinator to replace Hoke. ==Notable alumni== San Diego State athletics have contributed richly to the [[National Football League]] (NFL). Distinguished NFL head coaches were proud members of the Aztec Football program: * [[Joe Gibbs]] - [[Pro Football Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame]] NFL [[head coach]] of the [[Washington Redskins]], Super Bowl winning coach, NASCAR team owner, former Aztec player and assistant coach. * [[John Madden (football)|John Madden]] - [[Pro Football Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame]] AFL/NFL [[head coach]] of the [[Oakland Raiders]], Super Bowl winning coach, former Aztec assistant coach. * [[Don Coryell]] - Former NFL [[head coach]] of the [[San Diego Chargers]], former Aztec [[head coach]]. * [[Ted Tollner]] - Current NFL [[assistant coach]] for the [[Oakland Raiders]], former [[assistant coach]] of the [[Detroit Lions]], [[San Francisco 49ers]] and [[San Diego Chargers]], former Aztec head coach. * [[Herman Edwards]] - NFL [[head coach]] of the [[New York Jets]] and [[Kansas City Chiefs]], former Aztec player. * [[John Fox (football coach)|John Fox]] - Current NFL [[head coach]] of the [[Denver Broncos]], former NFL [[head coach]] of the [[Carolina Panthers]], former Aztec player. * [[Sean Payton]] - NFL [[head coach]] of the [[New Orleans Saints]], Super Bowl Winning Coach, former Aztec offensive assistant, former Aztec running backs coach * [[Tom Cable]] - Former NFL [[head coach]] of the [[Oakland Raiders]], former Aztec assistant coach * [[Brian Billick]] - Former NFL [[head coach]] of the [[Baltimore Ravens]], Super Bowl Winning Coach, former Aztec assistant coach Some of the more famous San Diego State students to later star in the NFL are: * [[Marshall Faulk]] - [[Pro Football Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame]], 7-time [[Pro Bowl]] [[running back]] for the [[Indianapolis Colts]] and [[St. Louis Rams]]. * [[Dennis Shaw]] - 1970 [[AFC Offensive Rookie of the Year]], played eight years in the NFL for the Buffalo Bills, St. Louis Cardinals, New York Giants, and Kansas City Chiefs. * [[Dan McGwire]] - QB was the 16th pick in 1991 by the [[Seattle Seahawks]], playing six years in the NFL. Dan is the brother of former [[Major League Baseball|Major League]] slugger [[Mark McGwire]]. * [[Brian Sipe]] - [[NFL]] quarterback; part of the "[[Kardiac Kids]]" for the [[Cleveland Browns]]. * [[Isaac Curtis]] - 4-time [[Pro Bowl]] [[wide receiver]] for the [[Cincinnati Bengals]]. * [[Kirk Morrison]] - Star linebacker for the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]]. * [[Kassim Osgood]] - 3-time [[Pro Bowl]] [[wide receiver]] and top [[special teams]] player for the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] - All American transfer from Cal Poly. * [[Roberto Wallace]] - [[NFL]] Wide receiver for the [[Miami Dolphins]]. * [[Fred Dryer]] - [[NFL]] Defensive end for the [[New York Giants]] and [[Los Angeles Rams]]. Film and television actor, notably starring in the series [[Hunter]]. . *See [[:Category:San Diego State Aztecs football players|List of San Diego State Football Players]] ==Facilities== The football team plays at [[Qualcomm Stadium]] (formerly known as "Jack Murphy" Stadium).
